user_review: A friend told me to try this and oh am I in love with this. I don't usually enjoy sweet food, but when I do, I DO. The macaroons are the best traditional macaroons I have ever tried here in Montreal. The panna cota gives me 2 AM cravings.
The almond chocolatine is to die for!!!Definitely worth a visit if you are in Montreal.

The macaroons here are better than Laudrée and Pierre Hermé and I'm huge fans of both locations in Paris. I probably went to Christian Faure 5 times while  vacationing in Montréal. Don't skip on the black currant because it's amazing!

Croissants were an airy delight. Come earlier in the day to ensure a healthy supply of pastry   FOOD:Croissants: Cross section photo says more than words ever could. I did find myself wishing they had infused a tad more butter--while the first bite was divine (compressing the dozens of layers with a bite and watching it all spring back!), subsequent chews revealed the innermost layers to have almost a bready consistency and sheen. Pain au chocolat: the chocolate filling may not be high in volume, but given the richness and darkness, it's sufficient. Almond croissant: lovely filling and flavor. As expected, the almond topping and filling does weigh down the pastry quite a bit, so it looks quite flat compared to its airier plain brethren. Chocolate almond croissant: thankfully not swimming in filling. One of the few successful ones I've tasted in the world in that you can finish one without feeling like you've set a record for sugar consumption. The real hit, however, was the passion fruit, lemon, and raspberry tart, and I wish we had more time in Montreal so we could try more of the desserts here. The filling was the perfect balance of sweet, tropical, and tart and among the smoothest (without being gelatinous) I've ever had. The crust was supportive but did not eclipse the tart flavor (with excessive butter). SERVICE: very polite and nonjudgmental given that it's chic inside and I showed up sweaty in running gear haha. AMBIANCE: Cute cafe space just off the main drag (near Notre Dame) with separate seating line from to go orders. Would love to have brunch or pastry & coffee here with mroe time!

Mamie Clafoutis offers a wide range of pastries and desserts. We didn't try much of their bakery items, but opted to try their cakes instead. The first we got as a flan, and the second was a passion fruit and raspberry tart.The flan was pretty basic. Nothing really exceptional about it, but it tasted as it should've.The passion fruit and raspberry tart, however, was very delicious. I really enjoyed the combination of the two fruits and the tart/crust itself was a really nice balance to the filling, not that it was incredibly sweet either.

I absolutely adore their passion fruit raspberry tart! It's not too sweet and it's the perfect summer dessert. I keep coming back for this again and again for many occasions. They write a lovely personalized message on the tart too if you request it. Not a huge fan of everything they make as I find other things a bit too sweet but the tart is to die for. A bit on the pricier side (Approximately $40 before tax for the tart in the photos) but it's simply delicious!

Cute and chic patisserie located in Old Montreal. Upon entering, prepare to be amazed by the presentation of the desserts on display. You have two options: wait in line for to go items or sit down and prepare to be served. The professional and efficient wait staff will come around with trays laden with mini-French pastries to choose from.  Unfortunately, we didn't get to spend much time inside since we had to catch a tour, but we did get to try the tarte meringue citron and the strawberry tart with custard. Highly recommend, especially the tarte meringue citron. I can't say how it compares to other Montreal patisseries, but if you're going to be in Montreal, this one is conveniently located and is worth checking out.

I love this pastry place gem found in one of the most tourist areas in Montreal. Everything was so delicious. And at fantastic value.I had the Coconut gelato with a decaf espresso. The coconut gelato was creamy and decadent. The decaf expresso was perfectly done - just like in Paris or Milan. This was a perfect little stop right before dinner. I also got the super buttery brioche and a chocolate croissants to go. Both pastries are fluffy, light, and airy. My sister, my nieces, and I devoured it within minutes. We will definitely be back!

Decent place for breakfast, but felt that the "brunch plate" was a bit overpriced.  It came with a coffee, puffed pastry and a small little baked pastry over smoked salmon + a hollandaise sauce and the whole thing was relatively expensive. While the croissants were airy and the pastries were delicious, I felt the value here was lacking, especially on the sit down side of things. I'd probably come back here for a pastry or two and a coffee, but would avoid coming here hangry for breakfast and seeking a main meal.

Everything here from lunch to dessert was amazing. It was our first food stop in Montreal, so boy did we have high expectations. And this place did not disappoint. The tuna salad was absolutely amazing. It was wonderfully fresh and the dressing was perfect. My husband's dish was also very good. Then when we were ready for dessert, the server simply brings the tray with every single dessert they have to youe table. That may have been one of the hardest decisions of the trip  The tartlete was amazing.....but the mille feuille was my favorite (we went back a second time just for dessert).For amazing French desserts, do not leave this place off your list. You won't regret it.
Amazing pastries and amazing coffee. I could eat their croissants by the dozen, I don't think I've been to a patisserie this good in a while.

Popped into Maison Christian Faure while wandering Old Montreal.  It's a little hard to find but worth it.  We were a little tired from walking around so decided to dine in.  Wait staff was very friendly and brought water right away.   Even though we ha just eyed all the desserts we asked for the dessert tray.  Waitress brought over so we could pick.She also answered our questions on what was what so we ordered away.  Everything was so good.  Full of flavor and not overly sweet.  Place isn't cheap but most good bakeries aren't.  I'd recommend a stop if you're in Old Montreal.

From Quebec to New York, my friends and I needed a break. Montreal was on the way so we stopped by here for lunch around 2pm.It was a snowy day. When we walked in, it was almost empty. By the time we left, it was three fourths packed. One friend told me that he tried to come here during the summer but couldn't because it was too packed. I sensed that we lucked out today.I got an espresso and the royal lunch. The espresso was standard I guess. I liked the daily lunch special because it was this croissant stuffed with cheese, some italian style spread, and mozzarella on top with an easy egg on the side and salad. The croissant added a crunch that complemented the cheese and egg. The spread had texture like ground up capers, and its saltiness really brought the whole thing together. I liked that.My friend ordered the kale salad. He was upset that it came with 3 slabs of raw salmon because it wasnt listed on the menu. I didnt care because he gave me that lax.The royal lunch comes with a tray of pastry and you only get to choose one. I saw a waiter describing each pastry to other parties and he was serving us since the beginning so I expected him to do the same for us.But then a French Canadian woman just stepped in and gave the breakdown. My friends loved it but I didn't like the descriptions. They weren't that detailed.This wasn't an issue because I knew what I wanted beforehand - the rasberry passion fruit tart. The tart was really good. Jelly like on top, crumbly berry paste in the inside, encased in a hard shell. Lots of texture. Delightful. If I could, I would come back and order this again.When we were done, we went to the bathroom on 4th floor. It was cool to understand how the patisserie is vertically integrated with its own culinary school, office space, and common area to hold birthday parties. I got to sit on the couch in front of the elevator, and it felt good after filling meal.If I could, I would stick to the pastries and try most of them. If I'm ever in Montreal, I want to come back. I only spent a few hours in Montreal anyway so I'll find a reason to come back, nah mean.

Absolutely the best croissant and palmier I've ever had. (I've done my share of taste testing throughout Paris and across the US). It was not very busy but I could see it getting that way, they had a line for staying and "to-go" They also have packaged goods and the ice cream cake looked incredible too. I also came back and tried a praline macaron, very good!

Disappointed given the high reviews for this place...The waitstaff were pretty unfriendly with us (is it because we're Americans??), and neglected to bring water to our table even after we asked them. We tried a chocolate and a passionfruit tart. They were both a little too sweet. The crunchy outer shell and the cream within were pretty good, but the steep price of around $9 CAD for each small tart was rather ridiculous.

An aesthetically pleasing dessert spot in Old Montreal! They have a variety of French pastries and desserts to choose from. I got the Savarin agrume chantilly tart, Milles feuilles, Lemon tart, Éclairs, Mont blanc & Raspberry passion fruit tart! All of them were delicious!

We came here on a good tour and received a free macaron.  I have never been a big fan of macarons but they were very good.   I got the caramel macaron and was impressed.  Soft and creamy! If you like these types of desserts, this is your place!

Small chic Parisienne patisserie in the heart of Montreal. Serving and treats were good. Friendly staff. Sweet little escape for desserts during our visit last Jan 2020. Recommended for the good quality sweet cravings!

OMG run and get all their cakes. So good, fresh, delicate and amazing combinations.I'm so upset I couldn't eat more of them in one sitting, I think I could fly to Montreal just to eat here three times a day :)

Wasn't a huge fan of this place! It's in a great location in Old Montreal near the water, but didn't have quite the cozy cafe feel I was hoping for.We came in to escape the cold for a bit. There's a lovely display of their pastries and desserts when you walk in and you can either stand in line for take out or sit down. They also serve brunch and have a separate menu for that. If you're sitting for pastries, they bring you a huge tray of what is available that day so you can look for yourself instead of walking back and forth to the display case at the front. But they didn't have all the options like the croissants and macarons :( We ended up getting two drinks and desserts- Americano: standard- Hot chocolate: really good! but gets sweet after a while. I definitely cannot finish this on my own- Vanilla layered pastry: The pastry puff layers were not crunchy.. it seemed like it was sitting in the refrigerator for too long. But the vanilla cream tasted nice and wasn't too sweet, which we appreciated- Pistachio macaron: again, not fresh.. it was too chewy! texture was as if I kept them in the refrigerator and ate them the next day or two... very disappointed!Wouldn't recommend or come back here.. There's so many other bakeries in Montreal to try!

Dessert Pastries for Breakfast? Why not? I am on vacation in Montreal after all!This is the second Maison Christian Faure location we visited. The first time at Downtown location where we got a cold shoulder as the lone staff was busy on the phone after we stood there looking at the pastries for a few minutes, so we just left.Luckily we decided to give this Old Port location a try and was pleasantly surprised by the hospitality even when the salon was busy.For Breakfast, we ordered:Passion Fruit and Raspberry Tart: Crispy sweet tart shell with raspberry coulis and mousseline cream with passion fruit- Pretty to look at and if you looking for a more refreshing taste, this is a perfect choice!Chocolate and Almond Croissant: Traditional French pastries with almonds and almond cream, made in soft butter and organic flour, with TWO chocolate bars.- so flaky and buttery and every bite was a satisfying as the whole pastry was filled with tons of almond and chocolate! I am sad since I could not able to enjoy this high quality pastry in Toronto on a daily bases but I am happy that I could enjoy them whenever I visit Montreal.

Excellent pastry shop.  I had a rasperry macaron as well as a caneles de Bordeaux.  The macaron had a perfect texture and was delicious and the canceles de Bordeaux I have never had.  It tasted similar to a cooked pancake with hints of rum and vanilla.  Very good.  Wish I would have tried more pastries but it was my last day in Montreal and I had to make sure that I at least stopped and tried something.  This is a definite must to try if in Montreal!

Lots of yelpers recommend Maison Christian Faure for bakery and cakes. As it is just steps away from my hotel, I decided to give it a try. I am not a fan of sandwich, so this review is not bias at all. We ordered a smoke salmon sandwich and Millie feuille tradition (cake) for our lunch. The portion of the sandwich is kinda small, but comes with lots of chips to fill you up. As a person who don't like sandwich, my first impression was "meh". However, after the first bite, it turns my impression to "wow". The sandwich is so good. Also the cake is impressive, love the overall texture of the cake.  I would probably be back for the cake for dessert, the sandwich is great, but small portion.

Very cute place to dine-in or take food and drink to-go with warm service.I loved the atmosphere and the decor of Maison Christian Faure. They have a wide variety of baked goods that they bake there on-site, and I loved seeing the trays being brought out. You can also peek into the kitchen and see them being made. Yelp said there'd be a wait but when I went in mid-afternoon, there was a slight line but it was really not much of a wait. I tried the lemon tarte and got other goods to-go for others like chocolate croissants, caramel pot, and chocolate pot. The lemon tarte was just the right mix of tart and sweet. Would definitely recommend as a fun afternoon tea break if you're near Old Montreal.

Most of the desserts that we tried were amazing, but I don't think it's worth waiting for more than an hour for. If the wait is 30 mins, maybe OK.Given the wait was long and the place was packed, the service was still pretty friendly. Funny thing was how a dude behind the pastries window kept asking people in line a party of how many, like he asked me probably 5 times and I had to keep saying trois trois trois monsieur! He wasn't impolite in any way though. I think he just wanted everyone to be seated ASAP.Once they cleared the table for us, we were seated about 30 mins later. There was a menu for drinks and actual food, but the desserts were shown in a sample tray where you got to look at the real thing (which were sitting out for the entire day so don't grab it and put it on your plate lol). After a detailed description and some recommendation from our friendly waiter, we got some chocolate stuff and the classic lemon meringue. Everything was delightful, especially the chocolate mousse with almond flavor! The lemon meringue was just what you would expect for a good lemon meringue. Some people are crazy about their macarons, so I gotta try some too - the cassis (blackcurrant) and pistachio flavors for me. I gotta say they're good but nothing spectacular so it's not like I would order 10 dozens to go...Overall the desserts were delicious but they weren't anything spectacular, and the crowded space made us hard to relax. If we pass by (who knows when) and if there isn't a long line, I'd go in and get a chocolate mousse again!

In heaven! Last and best meal in Montreal! My favorite salad is the Niçoise and they did it perfectly to my taste. Thick slabs of tuna, fresh crisp butter lettuce, not too much dressing, so refreshing!! Then I had to do a dessert (they will bring a tray out). Decided on almond tart and it did not disappoint. It wasn't too sweet and all the flavors and textures worked so well together. Will get a few others to bring home to Toronto .

Classy French bakery. Great experience!Everything was very tasty!We ordered a brunch on the plank with egg Benedict with salmon and brioche toast and cappuccino Croissant was buttery how it is supposed to beI felt like we were in France for breakfast!

Definitely on the pricier side, obviously it's in downtown Old Montreal (go figure). When we went, they were 10 min til closing. We didn't have the opportunity to eat inside. Though, the staff was friendly to take our orders, but you could tell they were ready to jet. Traffic sucks, so I understand why they were dreading with their facial expressions. We bought three desserts, adds up to $24 CAD. We ordered a strawberry cream in a glass jar, a vanilla berry log (almost like an eclair), and a passion fruit mini tart. Petite, beautifully made and crafted, and creative. The vanilla berry eclair was my least favorite but it was the most eloquent looking one. Passion fruit had a strong passion fruit taste. The cream jar one was very delicate yet satisfying.

If you're wandering around the Vieux Montreal neighborhood and you've got a hankering for desserts, Maison Christian Faure is a great pit stop. Food: We opted for dessert. If you eat in, you'll walk past several cases filled with delectable delights. Don't fret. Your waitress will bring over a tray of goodies right to your table so you'll have up close and personal viewing to help you make a selection, or two, or three! We went for the flan, a strawberry mousse and chocolate cake, a mango and passion fruit mouse tart with a chocolate coin topper. They were all unique and equally delicious. Mousses were soft, light, fluffy. Tart shells were crumbly when you cut into it. Flan was the perfect consistency. Service: You'll walk up into the seating area and you'll be seated by waitstaff. We were waited on pretty quickly and dessert was out not long after our lattes hit the table. Cost: Two lattes and three dessert items ran us about CAD$42 after tax. Overall: The space can be a bit tight as there's a line for take out and a line for eat in, but for those getting in and out, you'll have to squeeze into one of those lines. It can get loud inside when it's busy due to acoustics, and it can feel a bit claustrophobic at some tables. But the desserts are great so if you can manage the above, give it a try. Cash and cards accepted.
The best Macaron I've ever had. Not too sweet. Other pastries are delicious too, especially the almond croissant. Nice to have for afternoon tea.

We came here twice: 1) Bought the desserts to-go since the cafe was closing and 2) Dined in.I recommend the panna cotta dessert and the Framboisette dessert [it's a financier biscuit, with chocolate mousse and raspberry coating]. I also had their iced tea, but I didn't like since it tasted like passion fruit flavor (Note: The drink menu didn't specify the tea flavor or anything).I thought service was fine when we dined in. The server brought out the dessert tray and explained the dessert choices. BTW, they will give you a drink menu once seated, but there's no dessert menu to look at. We stayed here for an hour since we were taking cover from the rain and researching for things to do in Montreal (Note: They have free WiFi here).I'll return again one day. It was a lovely dessert cafe.
One star minus for the macarons. The top is crispy but it is empty and on the dry side. I won't recommend them.Cappuccino and mousse are good.

The desserts and pastries here are great and there's a huge variety - definitely something to please everyone. We decided to sit at a table in the restaurant which was very relaxing but there was a little bit of a wait. The place itself is very small so if there's a few groups ahead of you it might be a while.The servers were very friendly, but it did take a bit to get the check. I think our original waitress got distracted by a larger group so we had to flag someone else down. But overall the desserts were amazing and I would definitely get something to-go next time I'm in the area!

We loved Maison Christian Faure. The service was spectacular and the cafe itself is ADORABLE. We were on the wait list at spa scandinave up the street and wanted to kill some time. This place was the perfect spot to grab a quick bite to eat before hitting the spa.

Stumbled upon Maison Christian Faure which isn't far from our Le Saint Sulpice hotel in Old Montreal...what a gem! The wait staff was very friendly and pretty much everything we ordered, we fell in love with.The chocolate almond croissant is a MUST HAVE as is the apple tart...the pastry is just so light and crisp but not dense/heavy nor overly starchy...this was true French baking at its best!My Eggs Benedict was great and did not have the usual "too heavy/crazy rich tasting" hollandaise sauce but we every bit as tasty with the light foamy creamy sauce they used...We just loved everything here and wish we could teleport one of these Maison Christian Faure back to LA with us!

Amazing brunch place in old Montreal. We had the set brunch menu for $24 which included a drink of your choice, a pastry if your choice, and eggs benedict on a brioche bun with either smoked salmon or ham and custard French toast with caramel sauce. We had the smoked salmon. The eggs Benedict was amazing and the brioche bun was so light. The custard French toast was divine and the pastry was really good. Definitely is a must try!

There is something to be said for consistency...and going back to Maison Christian Faure 3 years later and having another 5 star experience is a great feeling!Their quiche is divine...perfectly buttery, flaky, and egg-y! =) And the dessert try is just as gorgeous as it was 3 years ago.  iIt was a very busy Tuesday afternoon and the staff were a little slower than usual, but after our meal was done, our server profusely apologized for the slow service which was completely not necessary but also a lovely gesture. Definitely a must-try in any visit to Montreal, both for the restaurant and the food.
We had an eclair, croustillant de pralin and a coffee. They were delicious but my only complain is that they took very long to take and bring our order.

Stopped by for a quick snack before our flight home. We were seated immediately at 5PM on a Monday evening.Ordered a house made ice tea and hot chocolate with whipped cream (both delicious - especially loved the iced tea, which had a perfect hint of sweetness to it), and the waitress brought over an enormous plate of pastries for us to choose from in lieu of a menu.We picked out the raspberry passion fruit tart (thanks Yelp) and mille feuille (my weakness) to share. Both were shockingly good, as I wasn't expecting that much given that most bakeries don't have many fresh goods by the afternoon. The tart was just the right combination of acidity from the passion fruit and raspberry, cut by sweetness from the mousseline cream and richness from the crust. Mille feuille layers were super crispy, which has to be a rare feat given that there's no way it was freshly made, and the filling had a fantastic subtle sweetness. Simple and perfect.Luckily for our cholesterol we came here on the last day, or we would've been tempted to eat our way through the menu.Greatness is not cheap, as the two drinks and two desserts came to around $35 CAD, but definitely well worth it in my books.

The worst part of your visit to Maison CF will be deciding which pastries you won't be able to eat.  There is such a great variety and they all look fantastic.The two of us chose three to eat during our visit and they were so wonderful we had to take three more home.  Light, full of luscious flavors, just perfect.  I'd make recommendations, but can't remember the names, must be the sugar rush after all the pastries!  But favorite was the dark chocolate item in the picture.The pastries are pricey, but worth every penny.They were busy, but our server, Harold, was just wonderful.  He took great care of us and helped us decide between the many choices.  Gracias Harold!

An aesthetically pleasing dessert spot with solid desserts as expected! My boyfriend and I came by to have some coffee and try some of their beautiful pastries which did not disappoint. We ended up getting three macrons, a passionfruit tart and a mille feuille to accompany our lattes. The macrons (passionfruit, pistachio + praline) had perfect texture however, we felt as though the flavors were a little too subtle for our liking. The passionfruit tart was bright and had louder flavors that were pleasant but we both agreed that our favorite dessert of the day was the mille feuille. It had just the right amount of cream and was light, which we appreciated. While the pastries are a little more expensive than your usual desserts, I think the experience itself is worth a try.

I noticed these folks immediately before heading to an early dinner and set myself up for having Dessert here instead.This spot is a totally different bag of chips from their sister Boulevard de Maisonneuve location: there's a pastry school here on one of the floors and Café on another. Just the vibe alone, this location actually seems more "formal" with a café flair, small tables, a delicious Dessert Menu and wonderful table service. While the other location over at Maisonneuve, you order from the counter and has a lounge-y type feel. Entrance here though, leads you right upstairs- giving you a sneak peak to their kitchen at the same time. And then- just then....you smell Butter, Vanilla and Chocolate in the air. There's a short wait- but don't give up, pastries here are worth the time and money. Heads up guys and double check.....(unless it's changed from the last several months I was here)- this location offers a quick nosh menu up to a certain time of the day. After that, it's strictly a Dessert Menu...so I was all in!!!Decided on a Chestnut Mousse pastry with the most sinful amount of butter in that shortbread crust. My Hot Chocolate or Hot Cocoa (not sure which), had strength and thickness in every sip.Service was excellent the short time we were there. Again- it's the pleasantries that I love about Montréal! I'd come back for Dessert again in a heartbeat.

Stopped by here when visiting Montreal for a mid- day snack before heading home.We came the night before at around 6pm but the dining area was already closed for the night (the dining area closes one hour before the store closes)We opted for a pastry tray of desserts ($8.50) this is where they bring you the whole tray to pick from. It was def hard to choose as they all looked tasty.I opted for a mango tart that was filled with white chocolate and creme brule. The tart was to die for! The tart was nice and light (not too buttery) and blended together with the soft fluffy mango chocolate creme brule cake on top. There was also some bits of chocolate crunch on the side to give the cake more texture. I also purchased some croissants to-go. Which were delicious as well. My favs were def the chocolate croissant ($3.20) and the almond chocolate croissant ($3.20). The plain butter ones ($3) were good as well. The place is suuper cute and a great place for a mid-day treat in the area!

I probably would have had a better experience picking up some pastries to-go, as opposed to dining in. Service was a mixed bag from various staff members, and ended up being a bit slow and sloppy throughout our brunch experience. I was also initially told they were out of a pastry I really wanted, even though there were a few sitting in the window... not sure what happened there. While the latte I ordered was sub-par and pricey, the quality of the pastries was generally good. My sister and I ended up with a Pâté Croute to share, as well as 4 pastries: Mont-blanc, Mango Mousse Tart, Framboisette, and Harlequin. Flavor-wise, I loved the Mont-blanc, with its chestnut cream and gelée de cassis. It tasted a bit booze-y, which was awesome. The other pastries were also good - but some had tart shells that were a bit too solid such that I accidentally sent a piece flying when trying to break off a piece of the mango tart with my spoon. We got there in the early afternoon, so the pastry selection was probably reduced by that point. I would probably recommend checking this place out earlier in the day, and would recommend taking out rather than dining in.

I think I might have gotten a sub-par experience because I came too early in the day? I stopped by at 8AM right after opening and it seemed like they weren't really prepared yet to start. The glass cases were mostly empty & they didn't have all the selection that I've seen in other pictures. Things I enjoyed: - Almond Chocolate croissant: I really enjoyed this! It wasn't too sweet at all and it just tasted so decadent. - Lemon tart: really nice lemon flavor & the meringue on top was good too. Things that were just okay: - Coffee eclair: I felt like the cream didn't taste that much like coffee. - Macarons: Like another reviewer said, it wasn't as fresh as it could have been. I feel like Maison Christian Faure is just outshined by other, more innovative patisseries in Montreal.
Absolutely fantastic. Yes it's a little pricy but oh soooo worth it. Classic French taste. Pastries run about $9. Coffee is around $5. Definitely a nice vibe and dare I say ... romantic!

Come early for the almond croissant, they run out quick. The strawberry shortcake is a little too sweet for me even though I received the recommendation that it is the least sweet among all the pastries in the tray. Chocolate croissant was fluffy and had an interesting texture.

We were here for a Yelp event and I am so glad I got to participateI've been here before but only walked in and out quickly because I didn't have time but was completely in awe with the place and the beautiful pastries and chocolates on display.We got to try quite a large selection of delicious sweets. I prefered some to others but that is definitely according to personal taste and not to the quality of the pastires themselves. Wow!!!!!My fav were the Montblanc, the passionfruit tart and the chocolate mousse cake, I tried a lot of different ones and those stood out the most in term of balance between sweet, tangy and bitterThis is such a great place for a lunch/dessert/coffee date or just-bring-your-mom-on-a-sunday-and-talk-about-aunt-Daisy's-new-beau kind of thing. Before leaving, I even bought a bunch pf my favs to go because I couldn't resist sharing these lil gems w my friends

It's probably okay for being in a touristy area, and the desserts are beautiful to look at. However, if you're willing to venture beyond the tourist spots/Old Montreal there are definitely plenty of better patisseries.First, the food. At first sight, I was excited and plagued by decision anxiety. Everything looked so beautiful and delicious. Eventually I settled on the "eclair Paris brest", which came recommended by some article I was browsing when trying to find some bakeries in Montreal. This was not great - I've actually had better in nice bakeries found in NYC and Philadelphia. The pastry tasted slightly freezer burnt and moist, as if it had been frozen and defrosted. The cream lacked flavor, even though it had a nice whipped texture. The candied hazelnuts were probably the highlight.Second, the seating. The place was small, but largely empty - save for a single table occupied by a parent and her child. I was actually not planning to sit and eat, but I had a backpack and placed it on a table while I was grabbing a glass of water after making my purchase. One of the employees began eyeing me, and I felt like I was doing something inappropriate. She said something along the lines of  "The sit-down prices are different from the to-go items" - I'm not exactly sure what she was trying to convey, but I took that to mean I wasn't allowed to sit down unless I planned on ordering from the sit-down menu. A slightly more apologetic tone or something to break the ice of this awkward policy could have helped - instead, it was Neiman Marcus meets tourist trap. I wasn't dressed shabbily, nor was I unfriendly. One of the few restaurant experiences I've had where upon trekking over and giving them some business, I was immediately made to feel taken for granted.So pass. I second the opinions of Yelpers about the lackluster pastry, on top of the misplaced attitude. It's not for me, although they've certainly streamlined the business to serve large crowds. They even sell their baked goods on their website and in other locations. It's efficient and brisk business, but I'm interested in another kind. After sampling multiple patisseries around Montreal, there's a multitude of friendlier, better options, where the baked goods are probably less frenetically produced on a large scale and you can taste the artistry.

Let's be honest about this right off the bat: this place is expensive.  Half a dozen macarons is $18. The millefeuille is over $8, the lemon tart almost $7. That being said,  once you have eaten the pastries here,  you will agree that it is worth every darn penny. The macarons are amazing.  Light.  Fluffy. Generously filled with smooth filljng with a dollop of fruit in the centre if you order a fruity macaron (mango-passion was my favorite,  followed by the raspberry). The millefeuille? OMG. I cannot sing enough praises for the millefeuille. Flaky,  buttery layers  bursting with a creamy custard middle. My tastebuds died and went to heaven.  Then the  lemon tart. Tart, yet with a subtle sweetness.  The meringue was perfection, sweet, light,  it was like eating a cloud. However,  the chocolates I bought ($16 for a small bag of truffles,  yeesh) was pretty disappointing. Loved how creamy it was,  but it didn't taste like $16 chocolate and expected more than it to be rolled in passionfruit sprinkles.So now you're wondering how I can declare this the best bakery ever,  yet give it 4 stars? Well,  I guess price is a big factor.  The service was ok; the girl working that day did not make me feel very welcomed. If you don't order a drink,  they have infused water for you to quench your thirst.

During a 3 days visit in Montréal, we went to Maison Christian Faure for breakfast every morning (our hotel was only 5 minutes walk from it.  How lucky we were!). We just loved everything they make.  Their croissants are sooooo good and we couldn't resist to eat them.  My daughter loved their sorbets (tried raspberry sorbet and strawberry sorbet) so much that she had them everyday even in -7℃ weather!  She also loved their raspberry preserve (it came with my breakfast set) and we bought a jar to take back to U.S.  We tried some cakes and they were sooooo good.  How come we don't have them in CA?

Nicely located in the heart of old Montréal. The bakery is small but feels spacious. Inside the restaurant is beautiful and super neat. The pastries that are displaying as you enter the restaurant, are mouth watering. The service is formidable. I ordered a hot chocolate and an almond croissant. Both were simply delicious and decadent. I enjoyed every sip of my hot chocolate and every bite of my croissant. I really loved this place; I can't wait to come again.

I was visiting Montreal from NYC for a total of 3 days and I came to Maison Christian Faure on two separate occasions. The pastries and desserts are honestly on the same level of quality as bakeries in Paris. Every single thing that we had was stunningly beautiful and absolutely delicious. The overall experience was amazing. We were seated by the window each time and ordered a drink as well. The pastries were all surprisingly original in their own ways and totally worth the price for the taste and the experience! The pastries are cheaper if you want to take them to-go and eat them across the street in the town square or by the river front, but we chose to eat in both times, and the experience is also super worth it!

Overpriced pastry and drinks. We had 2 hot chocolates and 1 rasberry and passion fruit tart and it cost a total of 22$...2 small drinks and 1 small pastry...The tart is delicious although the crust was a bit too hard. The hot chocolate was just a normal hot chocolate with foam. It came in a cheap mug with no presentation at all, no art with the milk or anything. The place itself is clean and it's a nice place to sit down and talk with friends. However, considering the price, I would definitely not come back.

I was walking around Old Montreal when I saw a family breaking into a box of the most delicious looking baked goods while sitting outside. I was just about to ask them where they got them when I looked a little past them and saw the sign for Maison Christian Faure. I made an IMMEDIATE bee-line for the door. When I walked in I knew I was gonna love the place. Beautiful, intricate sugar sculptures were showcased around cases of the most magical looking tarts, pastries, croissants, etc. I was overwhelmed. I wanted it all! I picked up a few packaged sugar cookies to take home to my husband and mom (they also love a good bakery) and made a line for the case. I will agree with a few reviewers that stated that it was a bit confusing at first but the staff was helpful and let me roll with the change in venue (I was originally going to take it to go but realized it would be easier to eat in). Typically one sits down at a table and they bring you a menu as well as a tray of the day's cakes and such. I kind of wish I had gone this route, so they could have told me what each treat was, but I just picked one from the case and they delivered it to me at the table, along with my cookies nicely packaged in a bag to go.The tart I selected was the passion fruit, mango tart with caramel. I sent my mom a pictured with the caption "It's so good I almost cried." She responded, "so emotional." I said, "I get very emotional over baked goods." Which is true! I can't get enough of a delicious treat. It's like, next level happiness to me. So here I was. Enjoying an incredible french sweet and living my Parisian bakery dream. Regrets? I have many. That I didn't come back every day I was here? That I didn't' get more to go? That I didn't get a blasted croissant? Don't make my mistakes. Get everything. You won't regret it!

Simply the best.My wife had been here a few years back for a conference, and she had talked about the experience ad nauseam ever since.I love my wife dearly, and take her opinions seriously, but honestly, I was skeptical. I was completely wrong. Don't be skeptical, be optimistic. This place is astounding.Macarons are their specialty. Get some. Enjoy them, because they are truly amazing - then, move on, because you won't want to miss all of the other spectacular stuff they offer.We enjoyed brunch here, and they make a great effort for a stellar experience. Salade niçoise is delicious here, so make sure you try it at least once. The real star, however was their quiche. Yes - real men DO eat quiche, thank you very, very much... This was way different than any two-bit quiche I had ever tried before. This was a velvety smooth quiche snuggled into a rich, buttery, and flaky pastry. Worth every cent and worth every bite. The side salad that came with the quiche was also high quality, not some wilted mess coated in bland dressing - this salad was vibrant, flavorful, and fresh. Really delicious.So, come on in - enjoy making your selections, and then relax, wait as long as it takes, and get seated for a delicious adventure! We will most definitely be back, and I hope it's soon! Merci!

Two words: Tourist trap. We got an assorted selection of their most popular desserts but not a single one of them stood out as particularly tasty or worth it. I was there just last week and I can't even remember how anything tasted because of how mediocre it was. Considering the location, it's definitely overpriced for the crowds of visitors.

This is one hell of a place! I mean amazing and a great place to stop by for a great pastry or dessert or coffee or dessert. Service is good and the are on their game, plenty of staff and plenty of people paying attention to service. I ordered the chocolate pastry with chocolate on the outside. It was to die for. The lattes and the lemonades and coffee were all amazing. Good job. Great find and all around 5 stars.

Lovely atmosphere, bright and welcoming. I went with two friends on a Monday morning for breakfast and didn't have to wait at all.The breakfast sandwich was good and was served with a great little salad. My friend's quiche was good, but was totally cold. She asked to have it heated some more and it still came back cold. Very disappointing. I would have given 4 stars, but given the cold quiche and cold response from the staff... I would come back, but with tempered expectations.

Certainly posh! It's nice that this place is close to the port. Considering it was freezing cold, I scurried back to my hotel room afterwards.The man who helped me did such a great job. I only wanted to know about certain pastries, but he pointed all of them out to me. This helped because I was indecisive, and I made up my mind by the end of it. He was very professional and pleasant. Not snooty at all! I got a chocolate raspberry cake, which was more like a 5 star black forest cake - but with raspberries. Very delicious. Even though I'm not a huge fan of chocolate cakes, I couldn't help but scarf this down. I also got a mango tart. The mousse was delicious. The cross section was gorgeous - between the mango flavours and the mousses and creams. The tart was firm but also not too hard to cut with a fork. I came here for the macarons! So I got vanilla as well as caramel. The vanilla one was delicate. The caramel one made me want to eat 10 more. Overall, a fantastic experience. I will definitely come back again.

Maison Christian Faure = the absolute best. Everything about this place is spectacular - from the mouth watering desserts, to the friendly servers to the fun dining experience; this place is worth visiting I believe if you're a tourist or not.We enjoyed it so much we visited twice during a long holiday weekend and my husband even special ordered a unique tarte tatin dessert as a surprise.Aside from all of the out of this world desserts, the hot chocolate is 100% worthwhile super decadent and delicious.Do yourself a favor and bookmark this place and go!

Cute little spot for afternoon tea or a sweet tooth. Why don't we have places like this in NJ?We tried 4 pastries and I'm still upset we didn't try the 5th (the lemon).My favorite was the one with apricot because it balanced the sweet with the tart. DELICIOUS! A must see.

Simply amazing pastries! I came here based on a friend's recommendation and I definitely was not disappointed. I had a latte (very delicious) and a mango pastry (forgot the name). Make sure to ask your server to bring out the pastry selections where they'll explain each item. Choose wisely. I'm sure you can't go wrong any of them but the mango custardy one was literally heaven. I also tried a bit of my friend's chocolate and rum pastry and it tasted almost as good as mine (not a huge fan of rum).  The service here was good when I visited but I can see it getting really busy during peak hours. They also don't offer iced coffee/espresso drinks during the winter.

user_city: Rolling Hills Ranch, Chula Vista, CA
user_review: Expensive but delicious. Definitely would recommend going and the location was convenient. I appreciate any place that has solid air conditioning. They also had a great assortment of teas! If I'm ever back I'll definitely make another stop :)
Absolutely amazing!!! Had a girls weekend trip with my sister and went here all three days! Beautiful and delicious pastries and wonderful service, truly the highlight of our trip!
Bad macaroons. Didn't have enough change for a 20 on a 13$ meal-- got robbed. Nice decorations but it doesn't make up for a place priding themselves on desserts but only being mediocre.

Super cute! I wish I took a picture of the Almond Croissant but I was so hungry and it smelled so good that it was gone within seconds. The croissant was flaky and it had the perfect amount of almond paste. I would go back! Keep Eating,Angela

The pastries here were excellent! My husband got a passion fruit and raspberry tart which he said was the best thing he had ever tasted. I got a chocolate and raspberry dessert, which was phenomenal. We also split the royal croissant, which had ham and cheese in it, and it was incredible. The croissant was flaky and buttery and just perfect. I wish we had discovered this place earlier in our vacation because I would have gone back several times! The coffee was just okay, nothing special, but definitely didn't take away from how yummy everything else was. The staff was very nice (and patiently explained all of the desserts in English to us) and the atmosphere was very cute. Not a large place, but perfect for a pleasant breakfast.

How did I not hear of this shop before I did ... little secret, some good friends told me about it. I am usually not a dessert over a meal kind of person - but this pastry shop could change that notion - right quick or "toute de suite"."Par excellence" and a bunch of other high end "haute de gamme" French expressions come to mind when describing this boutique in Old Montreal (they also have a Downtown location - for more central access to their decadences).I read Chef Christian Faure's bio (numerous awards and accolades) and was more than impressed. It's sweetly obvious this gentleman knows pastry. They even have a school teaching others to create the ultimate in goodies. I mean who wouldn't want to have a means to prepare tasty treats like they offer - in your own home or Chez vous.Let's just say in most cases I stick up for value above highly priced items, but we'll give the 3 bucks-a-piece Macarons a "price pass" this time. The exquisite factor more than makes up for it. It's like a magic taste wand.The box even comes with a neat printed paper belt which distinguishes their Macarons from any run-of-the-mill-wannabe-delicious-treats.They were a huge hit as a thank you gift, and disappeared as fast as you could say ... not-your-average-everyday-run-of-the-mill-wannabe-delicious-treats.Side note: The staff where in no way pretentious, as I thought - hmm, this is definitely the kind of place where you may expect to find pinky fingers pointing upwards. That not being my experience at the counter. I was pleased with the courtesy of the staff. Keep it up. Merci bien.

The chocolate cake was very dry! They also don't have the chocolate croissants in the evening, which is the only reason why I decided to try this place. Worst dessert spot in Montreal thus far. Don't waste your time! They really do look prettier than they taste.

Chef Christian Faire and shall I say Ouvrier de France owner is churning out unbelievable pastries in old Montreal. One must savour to understand the difference. I can't believe he opened in 2006 and I only discovered this now? Shame on me and anyone who doesn't discover this spot. I can't recommend enough. Bravo!

A must stop if you want to try out some of the best Montreal cakes and pastries! The chocolate cake was very rich and the vanilla and strawberry layered cake was unlike any vanilla and strawberry cake that I've ever had. I was reading reviews and like one of my fellow posters have said, Yelp ain't lying about Maison Christian Faure. The pastry shop itself is very cute and there are several floors, including levels where students learn to master the fine art of creating these spectacular pastries! My one regret is not buying the macarons and bringing them back home to Toronto. Oh well, next time!

I may be accused of giving five stars easily but Montreal has lots of great places to eat. This one follows the great tradition of French pastry as can sensed even from how the place smells. I had Tahiti tarte with mango flavored cream. The care spent in creating a perfect shape makes it really difficult to eat with destroying this peace of art. The taste was perfect contrast between the softness of the cream and the hardness of the crust. Friendly and helpful staff!

Grabbed some goodies for takeout for our drive back to Toronto Therr were 2 lines, 1 for sit in and 1 for take out so dont wait in line without checking!Got to the front quick after checking and wish i had a bit more time to look everything up and down before being asked what i want lolAlmond/ chocolate croissant, pizza in a flakey crust, strawberry short cake and vanilla and chocolate caramel macarons!The pizza was given thumbs up by the hubby, i had a bite and it was a nice change with the flakey buttery crust and nice flavours. The macarons were to die for and was so light, sweet and soft!!!The strawberry shortcake after a long drive on the car was still pretty good. The whipped peaks were still standing ;)The disappointment really was the croissant, too much almond paste, not enough chocolate or flakey buttery croissant dough! Got overwhelmed by the sweetness 2 bites in. So sad as i was looking forward to it the most!The star off was for the croissant and service, the gentleman who served me seemed a little bit stuck up and impatient when i asked what are their popular choices... he said everything! I asked what he recommends for chocolate and caramel favorites and he said chocolate...Will try other goodies next time, maybe will sit in would be better!

Had dessert and drinks with my dad at Maison Christian Faure....here are my thoughts:Ambiance - this place is VERY cute. Really loved the cozy atmosphere.Service - very friendly and desserts came out quickly.Desserts - I couldn't partake in anything because nothing was dairy-free, but my father, who never likes anything declared his Napolean "wonderful." He also referred to his cappuccino as "excellent." Since he rarely compliments anything this was an amazing surprise.Overall - Although I wasn't able to eat anything at Christian Faure, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this place to others!

One of the best deserts for French pastry. Their macarons are to die for and their pastries are amazing! I had the harlequin and loved it. The mousse in the pots was also out of this world. It was combined with so many textures which made it quite heavenly. Share the deserts when you got there so you have the chance to taste Mr. Faure'sbeautiful creations! Presentation and taste is 5*. We need more places like his in Montreal!PS: they make AMAZING lattes so make sure to order one when you're tasting all these heavenly deserts!

Stopped by for a quick brunch bite! This place is adorable with an ENORMOUS selection of pastries, desserts, and beverages. The perfect one-stop cafe!There's a separate dine-in area with a host/server to help you, as well as the option to just take your goods to-go. Excellent and quick service with possibly the best house-made fresh lemonade. There are seasonal menus for foods.

Phenomenal. The tarts are amazing. Got the passion fruit tart and mango lemon tart.Got the chocolate tart and chocolate something. Too rich for me. But still amazing subtle taste.Ambiance was lovely and cute French pastry shop style inside.Service was fast, attentive, and friendly.Overall, would come back again for the tarts if I lived in Montreal. Would come every month or every other week if I exercise.

Ice CappuccinoI'm not too familiar with coffee but it was good.Creme de LegumesUnderwhelming. I either don't have good taste buds or the soup was bland.Pate en CrouteThis was pretty good. The portions were small but the apple and pear jam went really well with the pate. And their foie gras was very tasty. I loved how the pate was not too salty.The cornichon was refreshing in between bites.Our waitress (girl with a tattoo on her right forearm) was very friendly and nice.

Came in for coffee and dessert. Iced latte was pretty decent and as well as their pastries. We tried the chocolate cake and eclair and they were both pretty solid in terms of presentation, taste, and texture. Overall, pretty average and worth stopping by if you are nearby. Not worth going out of your way to come here if you are a bit far away.
Maison Christian Faure is a must visit while in Montreal. The pastry shop will arouse your taste buds. Reward yourself, and visit Maison Christian Faure.

Macaroons were exquisitely delicious. My favorite was the caramel, but each of my friends had their own favorites (I think one liked the pistachio and the other the praline). We also bought a chocolate cake for my friend's birthday-- the chocolate was too rich for my liking though.

Mon dieu that was delicious pastry!As someone who loves sweets I have been dying to try Maison Christian Faure, a pastry shop in Old Montreal.  Christian Faure is a meilleur ouvrier de France so how could his pastries not be wonderful?  Well the opportunity to visit this fine establishment finally presented itself so I jumped at it.The shop is pretty large and it feels kind of sparse.  That being said there was some soft music in the background which helped give it some ambiance. It also helps that it is filled with aromas of fresh-baked pastries.  You have the option to sit down and order food or take something to go.  In addition to pastries they also serve main meals and sandwiches.  There is also a variety of sweets like marshmallows available for purchase.  Now I was in need of lunch so I ordered a quinoa salad which I enjoyed very much.  It was very refreshing and I still had plenty of room for dessert, because coming here and not getting one would be sacrilege.  All the pastries look so tempting but I finally decided on a chocolate mousse with raspberry topping.  It was so elegantly prepared that I was almost scared to eat it.  Doing that though would have denied me a wonderful experience.  The mousse was airy and the flavours were very well balanced.  I was very happy with my choice.The price tag is a little steep.  A pastry runs for $8.50 and my lunch came to about $32 before tip.  Once in a while it's fun to treat yourself to an experience like this but I couldn't see myself coming here all the time because it would add up pretty quickly.For the most part service is attentive and friendly.  I was seated very quickly and the waitress knew the menu very well and was able to describe all the dessert items in detail.  My food came quickly.  The only minor hiccup I had was that it was difficult to get refills on my water.If you're a sweet tooth then you must come here.  While the main dishes are pretty good the main attraction is the pastries which are some of the best in the city.  Their creations are bound to satisfy even the most discerning palate.

Such a cute place, with good food, and it smells delicious.  The have a lunch special which includes the daily special, coffee and a pastry...all for $23. Not bad, unless the special doesn't interest you. That was my case! I ended up getting the quiche which came with a small  (actually tiny) salad. The quiche had ham and bacon and was one of the best I had. Fluffy egg, flaky crust (not at all burnt), and well seasoned.  Got the Cappuccino which was very small for $4.50. That said, with the addition of sugar it was very tasty. I opted for a dessert which was a almond cake with an apricot mousse on top, really good. My bill was $26.90...$3.90 more than the special (no biggie). Anyway, the lunch menu isn't large, but this place is well worth the visit. I'm sure you'll find an entree, and guarantee you'll find a tasty pastry. You'll even find retail items for purchase (spreads, marshmallows, ice cream). FYI- the bathroom is on the 4th floor.

A really pretty and cute cafe! We weren't able to stay though, so we took a bunch of desserts to go, and the box was super adorable.Anyways, everything was pretty much as delicious as it looks. My favorite would be the passion fruit tart, strawberry cake, and Mille fuielle. There was one miss though - not sure what it was called, but it was small and circular and taller. It had the texture of an eraser.The desserts here are also on the pricier side - you're paying for the ambience and decor as well. I'd say it's all worth it though

Came in the afternoon for a treat with some hot chocolate. Picked this place based on high Yelp ratings. Staff bordered on rudeness at entrance and did not bother to greet even. Took a while before we were seated and given menus and even longer for someone to take orders. Eventually after we got our drinks and waitress came around with a pastry tray. We ordered and then watched as our pastries sat at a nearby table for 10 minutes before we had to ask someone to bring them over. This would have all been overlooked if the pastries were good but they were awful. We had the madeleines which were dry and hard and had to be dipped into drinks to make them edible. The rum baba (I think it was called), a round cake soaked in a syrup that was excessively sweet and tasted of uncooked rum was totally inedible, we were not even asked why this was not eaten. Will not be back. Much better on offer at chain bakeries on same street
very high end French style bakery shop, have breakfast here but no many cake can chose, better go here later.
This is a French bakery and very limited options for meals but the pastries were wonderful and the coffee even better. Montréal in general kills it on their coffee!

Ok we just cant get enough chocolate croissants. Or regular croissants. Breakfast here looked light but was quite heavy! I got the goat cheese zucchini quiche. Came with a great little salad at brunch. We also enjoyed espressos and ended the meal with some great little desserts. The only thing keeping this from a 5 was the rather confused waitstaff - everyone was helping everyone which was cool until no one was helping anyone and multiple tables were waiting on their checks. And the almost-too-hard crust on my tart.. it was really rough to eat. But delicious. So I would still go back.
Amazing pastries as all the reviews tell you. The almond croissant was out of this world. Make sure you get them fast because they run out quickly! The caneles were delicious as well.

Finally on our last day in Quebec found the best French parties we were looking for.Beautiful presentation. Real confectionary art.My favorite: Millefeuille traditionnel, perfect consistency and not too sweet as it should be.

This place is really cute and spacious. You are greeted by someone and asked to decide between eating in (sit down) or take out. We came on a snowy Tuesday on early January and there was only one more family in the restaurant. Prices are a little high and the desserts we tried, were overall, okay. They were not as fresh or memorable as the pictures conveyed, but overall they were good. For sit down they present you with a tray of French pastries to choose. Hot chocolate was really good!  Service was good.

Here's heaven: The Germans - organize everything.The Italians- in charge of entertainment.The Dutch - finance the whole affair.The French - caterers in eternity.Christian Faure is why the French will be pastry chefs in heaven. Faure ever!Everything at CF is stellar: from the pillowy raspberry marshmallow squares to the lemon sherbet, tarts, eclairs, caneles, all are of transcendent quality. I'm getting up early to go back for breakfast.

We happened upon Maison Christian Faure while walking the cobblestone streets in Old Town, Montreal. We needed a caffeine pick me up as we walked six miles that day. We are so happy we stopped there! It has a distinctive French appeal, a fresh and lively ambiance and the food and pastries are scrumptious!  It is a true French patisserie as well as a school. Yes, apparently Christian Faure is a master pastry chef and the building houses the cafe, the school as well as a charming event space upstairs. We shared a club sandwich that literally melted in your mouth, followed by a mango tiramisu which was delicious. The Americana coffee was strong just the way we like it. The kitchen closes at 3:00pm so get there before then. We just made it and were the last to be served lunch. Pastries however are still available. Please give this establishment a try when you're in Old Town!

Had a WONDERFUL experience here.  Every single staff member we came into contact with was so, so welcoming and kind - and it drove home to me how rare that is, when I'm in a French-speaking place, unfortunately. But the service here was pretty much perfect.The food also was, of course, wonderful. The chef deserves every one of the many awards he's received.We had a smoked salmon salad platter, a pastry each, and two drinks - courtesy of the deal we scored on their website where you can also get access to the Scandinave spa. The food was really good. If you choose to buy anything to bring home, it's SO EXPENSIVE - $14 for a bag of marshmallows, $14 for a jar of jam, $8.50 for a pastry if you eat in (vs. $6.75 for take out) - but it's all excellent quality.Wonderful spot, and highly recommended especially if you plan to go to the spa.

Not quite sure what the hype is about here.  I went to the Old Montreal location and the service was slow and the food wasn't as fresh as I would like.  We didn't get waters until the end of our meal and had to flag down the waitress multiple times because any time she would come by the table, she just dropped something off and rushed off.  The plain croissant tasted strangely artificial & reminded me of a Starbucks croissant.  The ham and cheese croissant melt was much better tasting, I would recommend it.  The cappuccino was decent as well, but nothing to write home about.

One of my favorite places for coffee and pastries. As well documented, the shop is part of the culinary school and a must stop while in Vieux-Montréal. All their tempting goodies are worth every calorie and carb. So order away.
Wow. Never had a praline eclaire like the one at Maison CF. So fresh. So sweet. So delish. Def a must stop for a dessert while roaming streets of old Montreal.

This place was such a let down after reading so many positive reviews. We came here for an afternoon snack after hitting a couple tourist spots in Ville Marie. Upon entering, we were motioned to take a seat anywhere (it was pretty packed with may be 3 open tables, so we took one). Someone will come around with a plate of pastries and will answer any questions you have about each. This is super informative and professional.I got the yuzu eclair, which I've been missing since Paris, and my cousin strawberry cake. The cream on and inside the eclair was pretty solid, though can get overwhelming (3.5 stars?), but the eclair itself.. so, so, dry and disappointing. Sure, the cream somewhat compensates? but the texture was just off. The strawberry cake, however, was even more of a let down - the cream was way too overwhelmingly sweet that it almost tasted artificial, though the airy texture was there, and the cake was also so dry that it tasted like it came from an overbaked box mix.Each pastry I believe was ~$6, unacceptable for the quality. We also waited ~45min from when we asked for the check to when we received our change (we gave a 20). We had to ask our waiter for the change, and it turned out that he had completely forgotten about/lost our change. Sure they were busy, so let's keep the 2 stars.Needless to say, we won't be back.
Wow wow wow, small but what elegance. We ordered the macaroons and you get them tax free if you order 6! Desserts are awesome!

This pleasant shop has a small variety of excellent pastries and good coffee and very good fresh-squeezed orange juice.  A hit with American tourists, make sure you ask for the pastries in the case to be presented to you table side.

This is my biggest disappointment in 2018 and I happened to visit it on the last day of the year. I won't lie, I was really excited about this place from shots of the sweets they have, but unfortunately it did not live up to the hype. When we went there they almost ran out of everything, so I had very little options I could try. I ordered some kind of tart with jam and cream on top. It tasted below average and 100% not worth the price asked. Tried other stuff my family ordered and wasn't impressed as well. How to put it...I was more impressed with the tea they served than their own goods. On the plus side service was good. Maybe they have better things to try on a good day when it's not so crowded, but I won't be there to try and I won't even bother next time I visit Montreal.

We live in California and my wife and I are fluent in both French (French "French educated") and English - having lived in the US for 45 years. This was our first visit together to Montreal with our two teenage daughters. We read a lot how wonderful this bakery is before our trip and decided to head for it on our first breakfast in town.  We ordered 3 pastries, a croissant, and a "pain au chocolat". My wife being gluten intolerant ordered nothing.  These are our observations:1. Wait time: there was not much traffic at the store and we were seated within a couple of minutes. The waitress (a young African American, I am not being a racist here, just giving a description to assist the manager in providing proper training to the right person) was cold and not very welcoming. Score: 3 Stars2. Order: it took at least 15 minutes for the waitress to come to our table to take our order. We first requested water (they bring you these half-full glasses (about 4 oz of water) that they never refill; we discovered that in Canada, ice water is a very rare commodity. When it was time to take our order, the waitress (a young, short and "grosse" woman who thinks she is bilingual (with very strong accents in French and English) and a very condescending and rude attitude tried to describe to us how to place an order. She brought to the table a tray of pastries and with her strong accent, tried to describe what each pastry is made of! She was so sure of herself and we were trying to make sense of the words she was pronouncing! Most of the customers were English speakers, and a menu with pictures would have been much better. In any case we just tried to place the order as quickly as we could so we cannot see her face anymore!  Score 2 Stars. 3. Food selection: we went there for breakfast after we have had coffee; so my observation is only for breakfast "viennoiseries". Their selection is extremely limited compared to what you expect to find in a French bakery. We are very familiar with French bakeries in Europe, and this bakery is no match in this area. The selection is extremely limited, albeit the taste and texture of the items we ordered were great. In summary: selection=3 Stars, taste=5 Stars; Price=4 Stars. 4. Checking out: a young man with a great smile and engaging personality approached us at the end to see if we needed anything. We asked for the bill which he brought few minutes later. At that time I told him that he saved the moment with his contagious smile. He was thankful and appreciative about my comment and he spoke great French without any accent (at the end, we discovered he was originally from Algeria). Score=5 Stars5. Summary: we understand our experience could have been much better if the staff was properly trained and cared about customer satisfaction. When you have a poorly mannered waitress dealing with you, it is enough to cut your appetite! As such, we have decided this is our first and will be our last experience at this place. Later in the day, we tried a gluten-free bakery "Le Marquis" and both the selection and the service were 5 Stars.  One more reason to never go back to the Maison Christian Faure located at 355 Royale Place!

Skip the croissants/typical stuff. The magic is in the different and delicious tarts, cakes and mousses. We tried 3 different ones between 4 of us and my only regret is not trying more. So good. Also, solid coffee.Go if you're feeling your sweet tooth.

This place was recommended , by the Hotel staff we were staying in, as a really good place for desserts and brunch/lunch bites.  We decided to go for lunch. I was like a kid in a candy store when I saw all the pastries/cakes/desserts even though I could not have them as they all had eggs. It was one of the few times I have felt tempted to try the desserts just because they looked so good. Lots of people there for lunch and to buy pastries/desserts for takeawayFood - We had Gazpacho for Lunch and my wife tried one of the desserts. The gazpacho was really good with Tomato and basil. Light but highly flavored and enough for both of us to share for a light lunchMy wife really loved the dessert pastry because it was very light and was not very sweet . The pastries were all so colorful and variety of tastes as it contained different fruit, custard, cream chocolate combinations. We actually came the next day and bought about a dozen croissants, pastries and cakes to bring home to US for the kids .... kids did not get to sample couple as ate them in the car on the journeyService - staff was friendly as they were willing to explain what was in each item and the relative sweetness. Ambience - simple small place with few tables if you want to eat-in. Was advised that on weekends there is a line to get a table on busy times fro brunch/lunch as many from the cruise boats also stop here as its close to the portPrice / Value - Excellent, Excellent, Excellent. One of the best placesImagine for the Gazpacho and pastries we ate for lunch and the takeout pastries was ~CN $60. If you are in Old Montreal make sure you go try this place. You will not regret it

Such a charming shop located in beautiful Old Montréal! I knew this place was delicious when I entered and could smell that rich, buttery bakery smell. It's very pretty and chic inside, with a lot of natural light. This is the perfect place to grab coffee with a friend or take yourself out. Their selection of pastries and macarons was impressive considering it was around 4 pm. Even though every dessert looked exquisite, I decided on a chocolate mousse cake topped with raspberry mousse with a  raspberry jelly center, and a latte. My latte was delicious and creamy with nice, thick foam. The cake was fantastic. It had a hard coconut(?) crumbly base  which was the perfect compliment to the rich creamy mousse. It was the perfect size too. Service was very friendly and helpful.I think this is a nice little "treat yo self" experience. Must try!

The pastries were phenomenal, although they were quite pricey for ~$9 a piece.I had a chocolate mousse covered in raspberry gel topped on an almond cake. My hubby had the passion fruit tart. Everything was so delicious.The service was not great. While waiting in line for a table, I noticed that the servers bring a tray of plasticized pastries to tables to describe what you can order. We saw one server patiently provide detailed descriptions of each pastry. She was very professional.Our server (the young one with braces) on the other hand, brought the tray and said to us "What do you want?". When we finished our meal, she took our  dishes away, and didn't come back with the bill and no one came around our table for us to flag. We waited probably 20 minutes and didn't see her again. We got up to pay at the counter instead and another server asked us if WE had asked for the bill. Well, we tried but no one came by! We paid and left.Fortunately the pastries were delicious but the service needs improving. I try to lower my expectations for tourist spots however they need to pay more attention to their tables. Luckily we're honest people and made sure our bill was paid before leaving but I can't say the same about others.

Super touristy (reflective in the price) and jam-packed.While the pastries are good, I'd rather not endure the disorganized lineup system and lack of AC in the middle of summer. Don't get me wrong, if you absolutely crave a good croissant or mille feuille at the Old Port, this is the place to be. But given the crazy level of tourist crowd and jacked up price point, maybe just head somewhere away from Old Port for your sweets.Beautiful decor, but unfriendly service.

The wife wanted some dessert after dinner and we found Maison beside the restaurant we were at. We walked in and no hello or greeting so we decided we would get take out. This was after dinner so there was not much selection left so we settled with a lemon tart and something.... to be honest the gentleman was a bit rude and I felt like getting rushed out. So we ordered two dessert and peace out! again no goodbye or thank you. We got back to our Airbnb and made lemon tea to go with dessert. We tried the lemon tart and it was perfect! not too sweet and not too sour but i do wish there was more of a lemon taste. Tried the second dessert, to be honest I have no idea what it was, but it did not WOW me at all... very boring.... but it went well with the tea :) Would come back to see their full selections, but so far it was just okay. Service made my star rating to be a 2 instead of a 3. A smile goes a long way =D

Holy Mother of Quiches!! This place has the best (lightest, fluffiest, yummiest) quiche I have ever tasted! It is deceptive from the street as it looks more like a patisserie, it is worth coming inside and having a seat.They have a full blown brunch menu with salads, quiche and soup du jour. I went with the vegetarian quiche and my husband got the cheese and ham. We both licked the plates! It was so good that we are still talking about it, nearly daily, a whole month out.Once you've eaten your fill of quiche and salad make sure to ask for their pastry tray where you will see a huge selection of their daily creations. I am a sucker for chocolate croissants, but EVERYTHING looked too good to eat.This place is a feast for your eyes and your taste buds. Make sure to check them out when you are in Old Montreal.

Let me be honest, if any one writes this place anything but a 5 star review, look at what they're reviewing about. If any part of it says that the food is the reason they are taking a star away, get that person admitted to a taste bud hospital. THIS PLACE IS OUT OF THIS WORLD. Ok so the owner has some prestigious title from France in the baking world, big deal, right? RIGHT, IT'S A BIG FREAKING DEAL! The products that are produced here are out of this world. I don't have a sugar tooth. My fiancee probably love me more because she gets to eat all the sugar filled treats when I pass. BUT NO, NOT THIS TIME. The fiancee will probably cry when she comes home later and realizes that I ate all of the desserts and we're not in Montreal anymore. We ordered a ton of stuff as we were leaving Montreal just prior to picking up the treats. A passion fruit tart, a hazelnut eclair, a chocolate mousse cake, canneles, and macarons. Was it cheap, NO, but was it worth every penny, YES!If you love baked goods. If you love French baked good. If you love a celebration in your mouth after every bite. YOU NEED TO COME HERE!

The first impression is EVERYTHING to me, so I have to say... this place "KILLED IT" (Meaning they are my top 3) in the "first impression department."Great service: The staff was friendly and are bilingual, a big plus for me.:) Fast service: The gentleman at the front was VERY knowledgeable of all the items, he sounded like the owner actually, which is rare to meet the Owner at the front desk, but if not, he knew EVERYTHING about all the itemsI'll be back, probably tomorrow..:) With regard to the actual desserts, OMG... that's all I can say Lolol. If you want find out, come to Montreal, google this name and go to "Maison Christian Faure", you are going to love it here.:)

Great service Amazing pastries (the platter selection comes to your table if you're dining in) Mille feuille was the best I've had, ever (even in Paris). Typical parisien patisserie ambiance Honored to be in presence of a MOF chef and we can't wait to go back to try the tarts!

Yelp should give an option of a sixth star and I would give it to this establishment.I am a Pastry chef and would die to go back to Paris to get that one taste of a perfectly crackly croissant or a well made pastry. Well, I did not have to travel too far from NYC to get the same. Montreal has Christian Faure and his pastry shop makes the real french stuff! We visited Montreal during the long weekend and the shop was quite packed. We picked up a couple of pastries and hot chocolate- and please do try the hot chocolate here- again a specialty which is as good as the french make it.We tried the tropical dessert, opera and some macarons. Ofcourse we wanted to try the eclairs and the mango passionfruit dessert too but it was just the 2 of us!! Everything was delicious and fresh. We took our goodies and sat outside as the day was quite nice.They also serve brunch/lunch which we hope to try during our next visit.
Amazing...I'm still thinking about their passion fruit and their mango tarts 4 months later. Best brunch I have had as well. Highly recommended!

Per Doctor Elsie W.'s review, we came here again. This past weekend might have been my third time in this place.I recommend the croissants with cream inside, along with the lemon tart, apple crumb cake, and cappuccino! If you're driving from New York City, try to make this your final stop before departing so you can bring lots of baked goods back!I saw a brunch menu, too, and I am looking forward to devouring everything when I come back again.Parking can get difficult on this block, so park around the corner by the public meters and just walk back. Walking sounds easy, but not in negative six degrees Fahrenheit before wind chill!

Very overpriced for over-hyped dessert. I came after my friend told me the dessert from here was something I had to try, as it is legendary and very well-known. I was very disappointed, especially considering how each pastry cost around $7.

Love this homemake Delicious french pastries, every staffs are very friendly and efficacy. The store is very clean and modern. This is a perfect place If you looking for a good coffee, high quality of patisseries , relax with friends. Will definitively come back. Highly recommend. 5 stars!!

You can NOT list the Top 25 Patisseries in the world, and not have Maison Christian Faure not on it...I really don't understand it. Is it his title: Meilleur Ouvrier de France (MOF)? The swanky décor? The Old Montreal location? The price points? Because, there is no reason related to artistry and craftsmanship that this patisserie isn't rated even higher than it is... on yelp, google, all the democratic rating sites...You'll find all kinds of elegant classic French pastries along with seasonal desserts at Maison Christian Faure (MCF) - classic in the sense that they are viewed through the master patissier's interpretation. Two that I'll bring up: Millefeuille and Paris Brest. So, Jacques Genin in Paris is reputed to have the best version of millefeuille around, benefiting texturally from the fact that it's made-to-order. MCF's version is pretty fantastic, and stayed in my memory after many months. But, I don't think I've had better Paris-Brest in my life.
